metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Role of functional groups in the activity of medicines

functional-group-role.name: Functional Group Role
functional-group-role.correct: Functional groups determine a medicine's chemical properties and biological activity

only carbon skeleton matters.fix: Functional groups are crucial for drug activity; they interact with biological targets
only carbon skeleton matters.action: Small changes to functional groups can dramatically alter drug activity

all groups have same effect.fix: Different functional groups have different properties and interactions
all groups have same effect.action: Each group type provides specific chemical behaviour

groups don't affect solubility.fix: Functional groups strongly influence water solubility and membrane permeability
groups don't affect solubility.action: Polar groups increase water solubility; non-polar aid membrane crossing

persistent.gap: Not recognising how functional groups control drug properties
persistent.action: Functional groups determine: solubility, reactivity, and target binding

hydrogen-bonding.name: Hydrogen Bonding
hydrogen-bonding.correct: Groups like OH, NH, and C=O can form hydrogen bonds with biological targets

only OH forms H-bonds.fix: H-bond donors (O-H, N-H) and acceptors (C=O, N, O) all participate
only OH forms H-bonds.action: Both donor and acceptor groups contribute to binding

H-bonds are strong covalent bonds.fix: Hydrogen bonds are weak intermolecular forces, not covalent bonds
H-bonds are strong covalent bonds.action: H-bonds are reversible; drugs bind and release from targets

H-bonds don't affect drug binding.fix: Hydrogen bonds are major contributors to drug-target binding
H-bonds don't affect drug binding.action: Multiple H-bonds create specific, strong overall binding

persistent.gap: Not understanding hydrogen bonding in drug-target interactions
persistent.action: H-bonds provide specificity and reversibility in drug binding

solubility.name: Solubility and Polarity
solubility.correct: Polar functional groups increase water solubility; non-polar regions help cross membranes

drugs should be completely water-soluble.fix: Drugs need balance: water-soluble enough to dissolve, lipid-soluble to cross membranes
drugs should be completely water-soluble.action: Optimal drugs have both polar and non-polar character

non-polar drugs dissolve in blood.fix: Blood is aqueous; non-polar drugs need carriers or modification
non-polar drugs dissolve in blood.action: Very non-polar drugs have solubility problems in blood

polarity doesn't affect absorption.fix: Drug absorption depends on crossing lipid membranes (needs some lipophilicity)
polarity doesn't affect absorption.action: Moderately lipophilic drugs cross membranes; very polar ones don't

persistent.gap: Not understanding solubility balance for drug activity
persistent.action: Drugs need: polar groups (dissolve in body fluids) + lipophilic regions (cross membranes)

ionisation.name: Ionisation State
ionisation.correct: Acidic and basic groups ionise at different pH, affecting drug absorption and activity

ionisation doesn't matter.fix: Ionised vs un-ionised forms have very different properties
ionisation doesn't matter.action: Un-ionised form crosses membranes; ionised form is water-soluble

drugs are always ionised.fix: Ionisation state depends on drug pKa and local pH
drugs are always ionised.action: pH at absorption site determines ionisation state

stomach and blood have same effect.fix: Stomach pH ~2; blood pH ~7.4; intestine pH ~6-8
stomach and blood have same effect.action: Same drug may be ionised in one location but not another

persistent.gap: Not connecting ionisation to drug behaviour
persistent.action: Acids ionised at high pH; bases ionised at low pH

receptor-binding.name: Receptor Binding
receptor-binding.correct: Functional groups interact with specific amino acids in receptor binding sites

any group fits any receptor.fix: Receptors have specific shapes and chemical properties requiring complementary drug groups
any group fits any receptor.action: Lock-and-key: drug groups must match receptor site

only one group binds.fix: Multiple functional groups typically contribute to overall binding
only one group binds.action: Combined interactions from several groups create tight binding

binding is permanent.fix: Most drug-receptor binding is reversible via non-covalent interactions
binding is permanent.action: Drugs bind and unbind; equilibrium determines effect duration

persistent.gap: Not understanding functional group role in receptor binding
persistent.action: Multiple groups interact: H-bonds, ionic, hydrophobic interactions

prodrug-concept.name: Prodrug Concept
prodrug-concept.correct: Prodrugs are inactive forms that convert to active drugs after administration

all drugs are immediately active.fix: Some drugs are given as inactive prodrugs that activate in body
all drugs are immediately active.action: Prodrugs can improve absorption, reduce side effects

modification always reduces activity.fix: Strategic modification creates prodrugs with better properties
modification always reduces activity.action: Ester prodrugs: more lipophilic, better absorbed, then hydrolysed

prodrugs and drugs are identical.fix: Prodrugs have modified functional groups that are changed in vivo
prodrugs and drugs are identical.action: Enzymes convert prodrug to active form after absorption

persistent.action: Modify functional group for better delivery; restore active form in body

structure-activity.name: Structure-Activity Relationship
structure-activity.correct: Systematic changes to functional groups reveal which are essential for activity

any change improves activity.fix: SAR studies identify which changes improve, maintain, or destroy activity
any change improves activity.action: Some changes essential; others tolerated; some lethal for activity

structure doesn't affect activity.fix: Drug activity depends on precise structure matching target
structure doesn't affect activity.action: Even small changes (e.g., adding CH₃) can dramatically change activity

all analogues are equivalent.fix: Analogues with different groups may have very different activities
all analogues are equivalent.action: SAR: structure-activity relationship guides drug optimisation

persistent.gap: Not using SAR to understand drug activity
persistent.action: Change one group at a time; measure effect; build understanding

common-groups.name: Common Medicinal Groups
common-groups.correct: Hydroxyl, amine, carboxyl, amide, and ether groups are common in medicines

only one group type exists.fix: Many functional group types appear in medicines, each with specific roles

groups serve no specific purpose.fix: Each group type contributes specific properties (H-bonding, solubility, etc.)
groups serve no specific purpose.action: Hydroxyl: H-bond donor/acceptor; carboxyl: ionisable; amide: H-bond

synthetic drugs avoid natural groups.fix: Synthetic drugs often contain same groups as natural products
synthetic drugs avoid natural groups.action: Body recognises and interacts with common organic functional groups

persistent.gap: Not recognising common functional groups in medicines

explanations.functional-group-role: Functional groups determine chemical properties and biological activity through specific interactions.
explanations.hydrogen-bonding: OH, NH, and C=O groups form hydrogen bonds with biological targets, enabling specific binding.
explanations.solubility: Drugs need polar groups for aqueous solubility and non-polar regions for membrane permeability.
explanations.ionisation: Acidic and basic groups ionise pH-dependently; un-ionised forms cross membranes more readily.
explanations.receptor-binding: Drug functional groups interact with complementary amino acid residues in receptor binding sites.
explanations.prodrug-concept: Prodrugs are modified to improve delivery, then converted to active form by body enzymes.
explanations.structure-activity: SAR studies systematically modify groups to identify those essential for drug activity.
explanations.common-groups: Common medicinal groups include hydroxyl, amine, carboxyl, amide, and ester, each with specific roles.
